docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton called on Congress today to pass legislation that would bar drug suppliers from charging the Medicare system more for prescriptions than their wholesale cost. In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton said that clamping down on drug overpayments would save $700 million over five years. He noted that a recent report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services found that what Medicare pays for drugs ''bears little or no resemblance to actual wholesale prices that are available to physicians and suppliers that bill for these drugs.''

headline.main: Clinton Calls for Bill to Stop Drug Overpayment

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton calls on Congress to pass legislation that would bar drug suppliers from charging Medicare system more for prescriptions than their wholesalecost (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: NO ONE was more skeptical about using magnets for pain relief than Dr. Carlos Vallbona, former chairman of the department of community medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. So Dr. Vallbona was amazed when a study he did found that small, low intensity magnets worked, at least for patients experiencing symptoms that can develop years after polio. Dr. Vallbona had long been fascinated by testimonials about magnets from his patients, and even from medical leaders. But his interest in magnet therapy became more serious in 1994 when he and a colleague, Carlton F. Hazlewood, tried them for their own knee pain. The pain was gone in minutes. ''That was too good to be true,'' Dr. Vallbona said.

headline.main: Study on Using Magnets to Treat Pain Surprises Skeptics

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Carlos Vallbona of Baylor College of Medicine indicates that treatment with small, low intensity magnets may help relieve pain; study is reported in Archives of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are few greater hazards to a scientist's career than perceiving a truth before the means exist to test it. Repeated assertion of one's insight will first invite insistent demands for proof, then skepticism, followed by silence, ridicule and often the loss of research funds. One who has survived this grave peril, with his sense of humor intact, is Dr. Judah Folkman, director of the surgical research laboratories at Children's Hospital in Boston. Some 35 years ago, from an accidental observation made as a young researcher, he divined that tumors must somehow induce the body to build the blood vessels that feed them.

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Judah Folkman; A Lonely Warrior Against Cancer

docs.abstract: Dr Judah Folkman, director of surgical research at Children's Hospital in Boston, proposed 35 years ago that tumors induce the body to build the blood vessels that feed them; for most of the time since, he has been a lonely voice but recent research indicates that his ideas have a firm foundation in molecular biology; now some 140 laboratories and biotechonology companies are engaged in identifying the chemical signals the body uses to construct and dismantle temporary blood supplies; Folkman comments; photos (M
